Now I believe in unions, I'm sensitive to their needs, I cried at "The Grapes of Wrath", I sing to Woody Guthrie. But that was another time, another place. Today unions are just a new kind of corporation. It's tragic, but believe me, those teachers making sacrifices for the union, well, the union's not going to make any sacrifices for them. Those union leaders, they go home with pay-checks, the teachers end up with nothing. Now we need people who can be dedicated, who aren't in it just for the money. Because this job takes courage. Do you know what some of these refugees have endured? Concentration camps. And now their dream of coming to America is realized, and this union doesn't care. It's all about greed. Selfishness. dialogues.text: Ronald Farber's parents are away in Europe for a few days, and he's  staying home alone without a babysitter.  Why do I need a babysitter?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Well, if you want to change Chloe's diapers…

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: If I didn't have any little brother or sister, would you let me stay alone by myself for a few days?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Your Mom and I are not Mr. and Mrs. Farber. We worry. So no.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (a beat.) At 13, I think you'll be okay.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: As long as you don't still look like you're 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL backs out of the garage and comes to the end of the 74.        INT.  BILL'S CAR - NIGHT. BILL looks tense as he pauses before the intersection.  H

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Hello, in Roseland, please. I'm looking for the address of a resident. The name is Farber… 12 Angel Court?… Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.  A sigh.  Suddenly the phone rings.  He answ

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Hi, hon. It's me. Listen, I forgot to ask if you could pick up a half-gallon of skim milk on your way back from the meeting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up.  Pause.  He steps on thegas. 76.        EXT.  STREET - NIGHT. BILL's car moves on, joining the traffic. 77.        EXT.  SCHOOL - NIGHT. The parking lot is busy.  BILL's car approaches, pauses. BILL'S POV of people parking and walking inside the schoo 78.        INT.  BILL'S CAR - NIGHT. BILL is suffering.  But finally he decides to move on. 79.        EXT.  STREET CORNER - NIGHT. A Street sign reads, ANGEL COURT.  Bill's car nears and t 80.        EXT.  FARBER HOME - NIGHT. A modern expensive house of the sort that, in this neighb RONALD's silhouette can be faintly seen watching TV. Bill's car pauses in front, then parks further down the b 80.        INT.  BILL'S CAR - NIGHT. BILL sits, numb. He pulls out from his pocket a handkerchief and a dark li He looks at the car clock. Finally, he opens his door. 81.        EXT.  FARBER HOME - NIGHT. BILL sneaks over to the side of the house and looks throu 82.        INT.  FARBER HOME - NIGHT. RONALD is lounging on the sofa, still watching TV.  He sn BILL slides into the house through a kitchen window. He tiptoes to a corner round which he can see the back of The phone rings.  BILL freezes.  RONALD answers it.

dialogues.speaker: RONALD
dialogues.text: Hello?… Oh, hey, how's it going?… No, Billy Maplewood's selling me his… Five bucks, big deal… Yeah, I know, but Grasshole can't stay absent forever. He'll probably show up tomorrow… Yeah, he knows he's got it coming, he knows… Oh, okay.  Yeah…Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL pours the bottled liquid onto the handkerchief. He pounces on the victim.  Within moments, RONALD succumb BILL looks around: the TV is still on; otherwise, silence He looks at RONALD, looks away. FADE TO BLACK. 83.        INT.  7—11 - NIGHT. BILL buys a half-gallon of milk.  He sees ALLEN riffling 84.        EXT.  MAPLEWOOD HOME - NIGHT. Bill's car pulls into the garage. 85.        INT.  MAPLEWOOD HOME - NIGHT. BILL takes a half-gallon of milk out of a plastic bag and

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL walks by the TV room where TRISH is sitting watching

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I think I have to lie down.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Oh, shit. I hope you're not coming down with whatever that Johnny boy had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL stops by BILLY's room.  Back issues of Boy's Life li BILLY is asleep.  A Playboy magazine sticks out from bene BILL goes over to BILLY and bends down.  He kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT.
dialogues.text: Lights out.  BILL lies away, listening to TRISH's rhythmi

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I mean, do you really love me? No matter what.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Bill. You have me. And you always will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She holds him closer.  A long pause.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Aww… Take some Tylenol. You'll feel better tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY walks along, despondent.  Suddenly she hears a Russia

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Joy! Joy! I am Boris! Your student1

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, hello, Boris. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: I am fine. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS sees JOY is holding back tears. He gets out of the

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm just on my way home.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Tell me where do you live. I take you home.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Joy. Come in my car. I want give you ride.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: But I like walking. And the train is right nearby.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: No. No train. I drive you home.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: But Boris. I live in New Jersey!

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Good. I take you New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Maybe you don't understand. Boris. New Jersey is far.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Joy. You not understand. I am driver. My taxi. You come. You understand? You come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS opens the door for JOY. She gets in. BORIS takes of 88.        INT.  CAB - DAY. They sit in the bumper-to-bumper traffic.  JOY turns to B

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Don't worry. Soon will be in New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The MUSIC on the radio swells as BORIS's taxi speeds alon 90.        INT.  CAB - EVENING. JOY changes radio stations.  They listen.  BORIS changes 91.        EXT.  MCDONALD'S - EVENING. BORIS and JOY share a little meal along the highway.  The 92.        INT.  MCDONALD'S - EVENING. BORIS and JOY sit in a booth.  They eat in silence.  Fina

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess it's best to feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. JOY'S PLACE
dialogues.text: BORIS's cab arrives, parks in front. 94.        INT.  CAB - NIGHT. JOY turns to BORIS.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well, thank you very much.  That really was very nice of you. I'm sorry about before…um…it's very unlike me…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat.) So do you think you'll need any help finding your way back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS is silent.  He stares off at her place.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, Boris. Life is different in America. Here a woman can – I know this is hard to understand – but a woman can fulfill her potential. There are opportunities here to do something, do good…really improve the world.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: It is alright if you are lesbian. I like lesbians.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Boris. But I think  this conversation has become a little strange for me. Thank you for the ride, and…um…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY extends her hand for a handshake, but BORIS kisses he

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh. Well…um…good night then. I guess I'll see you—.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But BORIS grabs her for another, longer kiss instead.  Pa

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Would you like to come inside for a cup of tea?

dialogues.speaker: INT. JOY'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Darkness.  The sound of a key jiggling.  A lock unbolted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes to the stove.  Turning back she observes BORIS t

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Yes, well…um…please take off your shoes. Make yourself comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS wanders around, observing.  JOY feels a little unco

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: It's my parents' place. I plan on moving out soon, though.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Since I was born. But really, there are a lot of advantages to not moving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat.) So what did you do in Russia?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: No. I am independent. I steal things on my own. Although I have many offers.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, no, not really. I just write songs a little.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know. They're all so terrible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (JOY shakes her head,  terrified) I play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS begins playing and singing a song, perhaps an Olivi JOY brings the teapot to the table and pours for herself They sit and drink tea.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Would you like to see my macrame collection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leads him into her bedroom to her showcase of macrame

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Thank you. I—I know it might seem childish, but sometimes I like to play with them and make up stories. These two here –

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lifts a pair of figurines) I call them Chuckle and Giggle. They always make me laugh…

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: You should build store. Start business.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (pointing to a doll) This? Two hundred dollars. Easy.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, but that's Punky! I could never sell Punky. I could never sell any of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS lifts Punky, puts it back, dirty now.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Don't worry. They're all machine washable.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: (a beat) You know, your English is really very good. You should be in a higher level.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (a beat.) Your face is like love poem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS is very close to JOY.  She lets him embrace her.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JOY'S PLACE
dialogues.text: Out of the darkness we hear heavy breathing, sounds of ne

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY and BORIS's figures emerge faintly from the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Do not be actress. Relax. Boris here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY quiets down. Then suddenly she cries out.  A still pa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS gets out of bed.  JOY listens to him gather his thi 97.        INT.  TEACHER'S LOUNGE - DAY. JOY sits alone at a table, perhaps wistful, or melancholy

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, they're just…great! And already I'm seeing improvement! But you know, the funny thing is…I feel it's me who's doing the most learning.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: I know just what you mean. 'Cause teaching is really about learning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pause) But really I can't tell you how… gratifying it's been…I mean, I'm giving…and they're taking. I couldn't be happier.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: I hate to have to say this, but: I told you so.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: How about you? How's it going with your class?

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Oh, my students are just a hoot, always telling me how much they  love me. But if you can keep a secret…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lowers her voice) There's this one Igor I've got such a crush on…

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Not that I'd ever…I mean, these Russians…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RHONDA lifts her arm, points to her armpit, mouths "B.O."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY'S POV THROUGH THE WINDOW of the STRIKERS still marchi BACK TO JOY AND RHONDA gazing outside.  Pause.  RHONDA tu

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: You know, Joy, just between you  and me, I actually think the  quality of teaching has gone up  since the strike began.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, well, I don't know. I just wish it were all over.

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: Me too. But you know, once you're here and you're teaching, it's as if it doesn't even exist. You forget.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Russian woman, ZHENIA, suddenly interrupts, barging int

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she lunges for her, cursing in Russian.  RHONDA, othe

dialogues.speaker: RHONDA
dialogues.text: My God! That woman was nuts! Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bell rings.  TEACHERS, ET. AL. Begin to disperse. JOY gathers her stuff, RHONDA helping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some TEACHERS pause to overhear JOY's anticipated reply. 98.        INT.  ALLEN'S PLACE - EVENING. ALLEN sits on his bed, tense and sweaty, gripping his pho 99.        INT.  HELEN'S PLACE - EVENING. HELEN lies on her bed, strewn with poetry books and paper The phone rings.  She answers it.  She hears only some fa

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Thank you for calling me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (no response.) I'm sorry if I was a little bit… aggressive last time, but…I wasn't… prepared…and I'm not very good… on the phone… But U have to… meet you… Can we meet?…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN hangs up and unplugs the phone.  Pause. The door buzzes.  ALLEN rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN hesitates, then opens the door. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. I shouldn't have…um…

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: I understand. See, I can admit it. I'm fat…ugly…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tears are trickling down KRISTINA's face.  ALLEN hands he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KRISTINA nods, grateful. 100.        EXT.  BAR - NIGHT. MUSIC flows outside. 101.        INT.  BAR - NIGHT. ALLEN and KRISTINA foxtrot by the jukebox. 102.        INT.  RESTAURANT - NIGHT. ALLEN and KRISTINA sit in a booth.  They are eating.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: I have a confession to make.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: You mean, the one that was…cut off?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: I—I don't understand. Why would you make something like that up?

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: Well, I'd always been very friendly to him. I try to be that way with all the doormen, even if they're usually snickering behind my back. But I don't care, I'm still friendly. It's my way. Well, Pedro was different. Pedro never snickered. Of course, who was he to snicker? He wasn't exactly Tom Cruise. Still, he could have, and he didn't. Well, anyway, one night…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEDRO opens the door for KRISTINA.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: …I had just come back late from the 24-hour Pathmark…

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: Hello, Pedro. Do you think  you could help me with these bags?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PEDRO locks up and takes the bags from KRISTINA.  They th

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Normally I don't need any help, but my back hurt and the bags were heavy. There was half-gallon of strawberry ice cream and a couple of boxes of fudge, a key lime pie… Really, I just couldn't wait to snuggle up under the covers and enjoy myself with the TV. You know…

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It was in the elevator that I first got a funny feeling…like he was looking at me kind of funny…but I thought maybe he was just being friendly…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get off and walk to her apartment. 105.        INT.  KRISTINA'S PLACE - NIGHT. PEDRO follows KRISTINA inside, brings the groceries to th

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: Well, thank you so much, Pedro.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But then he wouldn't move. I almost panicked, but then I realized he probably was just waiting for a tip. So I got out my purse…and then he surprised me.

dialogues.speaker: PEDRO
dialogues.text: Forget about it. What I'd like is a scoop of this ice cream before going back down.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, isn't that nice and friendly, I thought. Thought I also thought, that's a little strange. I'm a  little shy, you know, and also I had only one half-gallon. But he said, "Sure!" Well, then he sat down and started telling me about how he had no family, no friends… I started feeling really sorry for him…and I… Well, I guess I felt I shouldn't feel so superior. But then, all of a sudden, just as I was finishing scooping…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO ALLEN AND KRISTINA in the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: …He started…kissing me…more and more… and longer and deeper…it was horrible… horrible! Next thing I knew he tore off my dress, my…everything! …And he was climbing on top of me… He thought because I was fat and ugly I'd be…easy… that I…wanted it. I tried to fight him off, but he was too fast for me, and  next thing I knew he was…inside me, pounding away. Oh, Allen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KRISTINA grabs a napkin to cry into. Pause. The WAITRESS comes by.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Would you like to see a dessert menu?

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: What kind of ice cream do you have?

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: I'll just have a plain chocolate fudge sundae with strawberry ice cream.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: So anyway, everything suddenly got quiet and I thought, well, at least the worst is over.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KRISTINA'S PLACE
dialogues.text: PEDRO lies on top of KRISTINA.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, of course, that was just an act. I let him kiss me one last time, and then…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BACK TO ALLEN AND KRISTINA in the restaurant.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: …Grabbed hold of his neck and… twisted it…backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS comes by with the dessert.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (while eating her sandae) Anyway, so then I had to cut up his body, plastic bag all the parts… I've been throwing it out gradually ever since. There's still a little left in my freezer.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: So you did cut off his…

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: No, I left it attached. I didn't want to have to touch it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat.) Oh, I feel so terrible. You must think I'm a monster. But what else could I have done?… Anyway, I couldn't help myself. I hate…sex. I'm sorry, but just the idea of it…of someone all over…inside…me…I know it's not right, but… Can we still be…friends?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Um… I guess… Yeah… I mean, we all have our…you know…pluses and minuses…

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: It was a crime of passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN and KRISTINA come out of the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTINA
dialogues.text: I had a lovely time, Allen. Thank you. I hope we can do it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN has entered his apartment and is about to close the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN smiles weakly, then shuts his door, locking and dou 108.        INT.  ALLEN'S PLACE - NIGHT. ALLEN stares at his telephone.  Finally, he plugs it in.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I've had you on auto-redial all night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN hangs up and unplugs the phone again.  He sits down 109.        INT.  APARTMENT BUILDING HALLWAY - NIGHT. ALLEN comes out of his apartment and walks bravely down t A moment passes.  ALLEN covers the peephole with his hand

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELEN opens the door, sees ALLEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cannot disguise her disappointment, but tries.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HELEN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: HELEN and ALLEN sit opposite each other.  A long silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ALLEN walks back towards his door, pauses, looks at the o He buzzes KRISTINA's door. After a few moments, the door opens.  ALLEN looks at the 112.        INT.  KRISTINA'S PLACE - NIGHT. ALLEN and KRISTINA lie in bed, facing different direction 113.        EXT.  FLORIDA/ARIZONA GOLF COURSE - DAY. It is hot and sunny.  LENNY is golfing alone, isolated. Suddenly, from afar, he hears a woman's cries.  He looks LENNY'S POV:  An older woman is running around, hysterica After the ambulance has left, a young caddie picks up the 114.        INT.  DOCTOR'S OFFICE - DAY. LENNY sits across from the DOCTOR.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (illuminates an x-ray) You're the picture of health.

dialogues.speaker: DOCTOR
dialogues.text: Like an ox. Lenny.  You're gonna live to a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Oh. That means I still have another 35 years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONA is driving along. 116.        INT.  MONA'S CAR - DAY. MONA notices someone up ahead. MONA'S POV of DIANE jogging. BACK TO MONA contemplating murder.  She aims for DIANE. ANGLE ON DIANE waving back in a pleasant manner. 117.        INT.  MONA AND LENNY'S CONDO - NIGHT. LENNY and MONA are preparing for bed, watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I met with Steven Zimmer this morning.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Good. I'm gonna use Marty Blau.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Good. I feel so much better now.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. It shouldn't take too long.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Can you sleep on the living room sofa?

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: Steven Zimmer thought it would be a good idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENNY starts off for the living room, gets extra pillow a

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: You don't have to sleep there. You can stay with me if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  MONA turns back towards her bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MONA closes the door behind her. 118.        INT.  DIANE'S CONDO - DAY. LENNY rings the doorbell.  DIANE opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENNY follows DIANE into her living room.  She fixes a co

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She returns with the drinks, sits beside him on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Uch, it's so bright outside. It gives me a headache just looking out the window.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk about the weather.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: Well, it was good for playing golf.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I hate that game. It's so slow and tedious.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Have you ever been to Tahiti?

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: What about Tunisia? A night in Tunisia!

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: (laughs) You know, when I was a child I always imagined I'd marry the man I fell in love with, have a son and daughter who loved me as much as I hated my mother, then die tragically and suddenly, young and beautiful. Later, when Vincent left me, I imagined I'd finally be happy.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: I guess you've never lost your imagination.

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: Lenny, I've got to get out of here… I can't breath… The women are all… pathetic gossips…and the men…

dialogues.speaker: DIANE
dialogues.text: I don't want to die here.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: You just don't want to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They make love.  Afterwards, LENNY turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENNY turns back, looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: LENNY
dialogues.text: I don't. I don't feel anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The family is at the table, eating dinner.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: He was afraid of the math test.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: They don't know yet. They're still on vacation.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Oh, are they gonna be upset.

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, Ronald's gonna be upset when he finds out the test was cancelled.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Did you call Ronald and tell him?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Yeah, but there was no answer.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: So was Mrs. Paley sick, then?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, everyone says she was just too strung out.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Now why do people say things like that?

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Well, I didn't know. Did you know, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Well, it's what everyone says: she's a junkie. And she's probably gonna be fired. It's really sad.

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Well, if Mrs. Paley turns out, in fact, to be a junkie, then…she should be fired. Don't you think, Bill?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don't know. Don't you think that's a little harsh? I mean, if it's not affecting her work…

dialogues.speaker: TRISH
dialogues.text: Well, apparently it is. And no, in fact, I don't think it's a little harsh at all. I'm sorry, but when it comes to drug abuse…and children, my children… Uch,  they should all be locked up and throw away the key. I'm serious. And Billy, I want you to know, if you ever even think of doing drugs, and  end up dying in a hospital…I'd disown you. That's how strongly I feel. Now I know, Bill, I may sound harsh, but we're talking about our kids. Not to be too grandiose, but this is the future, the future of our country we're talking about, after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (answers the phone.) Hello, who is this, pleas?… Oh, hi… Sure, hold on…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (rises, picks up the phone) Hey, Joe! Whay's up? How's Johnny doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hangs up. BACK TO THE MAPLEWOOD HOME where we see BILL's reaction t

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: (fakes continuing  the conversation) Oh, good, good… No problem!… Right… Okay. Well, take care… Bye!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL goes to the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL opens the door.  There is a DETECTIVE and TWO POLICE

dialogues.speaker: DETECTIVE
dialogues.text: Sorry to disturb you, but we have some questions for you and your wife. It has to do with your son's friend, Johnny Grasso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a meaningful silence) Come this way. We're just finishing  dinner, but I—I'll be right with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL escorts them into the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL goes to the dining room, mouths, "The Police!" to TR

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You take care of the kids.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL returns to his guests.  They all sit down.  BILL is

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Sorry. Now…um…you said something about Ronald Farber?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I'm sorry…er…I mean…I mean, Johnny Grasso?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRISH is asleep, but BILL is wide awake.  He is terrified He thinks he hears footsteps. He looks up and sees JOHNNY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TRISH comforts him. 122.        EXT.  MAPLEWOOD HOME - DAY. Holding TIMMY's hand, TRISH comes out the front door in h A schoolbus is waiting at the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling inside) Hurry up, Billy! The bus is here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY rushes out after them, but is too late: the bus has 123.        EXT.  PARK - DAY. It is sunny and warm, the same park seen in Bill's dream BILL observes the pleasant tranquility from atop a hill. MUSIC SWELL.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Thank you. I take it as a sign.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Trish and I are thinking of moving. Out into the country. The real country.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: How are things between you and Trish?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: I don't know what happened, but all of a sudden, one night last week we were watching TV and…she turned me on. The kids went to bed and…we fucked. And on the weekend… in the morning, too…we fucked.          My life is just one big fuck!

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: Thanks. But you know it's strange… I mean how like…now…just like that… everything's normalized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long pause.  Then BILL rises.

dialogues.speaker: PSYCHIATRIST
dialogues.text: There's still ten minutes. Nothing more you want to discuss?

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: No, I guess not. Everything's fine.

dialogues.text: BILL walks towards the door, but stops before a photograp

dialogues.text: Everyone at school is saying things about you.

dialogues.speaker: BILL
dialogues.text: You mean, like what they painted on the house?

dialogues.speaker: BILLY
dialogues.text: Dad…did you…did you…with Johnny Grasso and Ronald Farber…?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILL weeps. 127.        INT.  BILL AND TRISH'S BATHROOM - NIGHT. BILL swallows half a dozen sleeping pills. 128.        EXT.  MAPLEWOOD HOME - NIGHT. A car drives up and idles out front.  DRUNKEN TEENAGERS l

dialogues.text: He searches the rest of the house, though somewhat perfun

JOY climbs a few flights of stairs, arrives at a door wit ZHENIA opens the door.  She has a black eye and a cut lip

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh…er…I'm sorry…I just wanted to… er…Here…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY shoves her bouquet of flowers into ZHENIA's hand.  Sh

dialogues.text: ZHENIA abandons JOY at the door and goes back inside, mut BORIS appears at the door, surprised to see her.  Oddly,

dialogues.speaker: INT. BORIS AND ZHENIA'S PLACE
dialogues.text: JOY sits opposite BORIS.  ZHENIA brings her a cup of tea.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Joy. Why are you come here?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to…um…say I was sorry…to your wife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY looks confused, perhaps even suspicious.  BORIS shout

dialogues.speaker: ZHENIA
dialogues.text: (to JOY) I am not wife Boris.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he dismisses her once more.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Her English very bad. I try teach, but Zhenia…slow.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: So you mean you're really not married?

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: (laughs) I am in America! I am free man!

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Zhenia loves me. It is problem. She want be my wife, but she don't listen. What can I do? What can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat.) Come. You want me to drive you New Jersey? We go shopping mall?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No, thank you. I don't think that's really…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY suddenly notices her guitar lying against the wall op When things cool down ZHENIA brings over a tray with past

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Joy. I must ask you question.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well, I guess it's better borrowing than stealing…

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOY glances over at ZHENIA standing at the other end of t

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Alright. Five hundred. I need money now.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: W-well I guess I could go to a cash machine…

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Do you think I could have my guitar back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS and JOY, guitar in hand, are walking.

dialogues.speaker: BORIS
dialogues.text: Do you think shopping mall in New Jersey is open tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop outside a bank.  JOY withdraws her money from t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, embraces JOY.) I give you back Monday.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: That's okay. I won't be there, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: I don't know, but for some reason… now I have more sympathy for the strikers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS watches JOY walk away with her guitar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BORIS pockets his money and walks off in the opposite dir

dialogues.text: BILLY stands on the terrace and looks down.  He sees palm KOOKI stands beside him. 141.        INT.  BOCA RATON CONDOMINIUM - DAY. LENNY, MONNA, HELEN, TRISH, and JOY sit at a long table f

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: …Anyway, so the police came and looked in her freezer and found baggies filled with the super's genitals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause.  LENNY salts his food, a heavy dose.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Everyone uses baggies. That's why we can all relate to the crime. Don't you see?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: …In any case, there's a guy I've met, Joy, that I think you'd like. He's into computers, I think,

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: He's another neighbor of mine. Do you wanna call him, or should I give him your number?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Oh, great. I know he'd really like that.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Trish, trust me on this one: not for you.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Mom, I haven't forgotten. It's just it's hard. But I am looking for everyone.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: I heard Diane Fred had a stroke.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Could you pass over the sweet potatoes, please?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: Could you pass down the stuffing, please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone shakes his head or mumbles no. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: MONA
dialogues.text: So what's going to happen now to that woman who killed your super?

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I don't know, Mom. But it's so sad. She's all alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a beat.) I wish I'd gotten to know her better. We might have found we had something in common.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Maybe you'll write a poem about her.

dialogues.speaker: HELEN
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. But don't worry. I'm not laughing at you. I'm laughing with you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HELEN stops laughing. 142.        EXT.  CONDOMINIUM TERRACE - DAY. CLOSE ON BILLY as his face expresses mounting excitement. BILLY'S POV of the beautiful woman sunbathing.  She unhoo BACK TO BILLY climaxing.  CLOSE ON COOKI licking up BILLY 143.        INT.  CONDOMINIUM - DAY. The meal is painfully silent.  Finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasses clink.  Some hesitation before everyone downs the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BILLY enters.  He is ecstatic.  Tears well up in his eyes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA DOLLIES across the living room and bedrooms. MONA rises to the terrace, her eyes silently welling with

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Don't, Mom. 'Cause the thing about family is…no matter how distant you are from each other, separated, estranged, divorced, whatever…no matter how little you can relate to each other…it doesn't matter: you're still family. You're not along… Ya see?

dialogues.speaker: BLACK.
dialogues.text: The sound of a telephone ringing.  Then:

dialogues.speaker: INT. ALLEN'S PLACE
dialogues.text: JOY stands at a payphone, a placard resting on her should ALLEN sits half undressed on his bed, phonebook at his si BOUNCY MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hello. Could I please speak to Allen Mellencamp?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Well, my sister Helen told me I should call you.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Oh, then you must be Joy. Hi.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Hi. Gee, you sound so familiar.

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: But in a good way, a way I like.

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Say, what are you wearing, I mean doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing special. Would you like to get together?

dialogues.speaker: ALLEN
dialogues.text: Yeah. I know a great place off Exit 146. Have you heard of Happy's?

dialogues.speaker: JOY
dialogues.text: No. It's great. Let's meet there at eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They hang up, happy, perhaps even smitten.
